column2: Shoreview grew rapidly. Residential dwellings tripled after 1970.  During the 1990s growth slowed as the city matured and less land was available for development. The focus of the city has shifted from new development to infill and redevelopment. In the late 2010s
column3: there have been multiple renovation projects. Future projections indicate a stable population base.

column1: The Shoreview City Council consists of a Mayor and four council members.  The Mayor serves a two-year term of office
column2: and the council members are elected at–large to serve overlapping four year terms.  Shoreview has adopted the Plan B Council/Manager form of government
column3: one of three forms permitted by the Minnesota State Legislature.  The Council has policymaking and legislative authority and appoints the City Manager
column4: who is charged with the administration of city business in accordance with council decisions.  The Manager has the authority to appoint all employees and is responsible for the development of the annual budget.

column1: Shoreview is financially sound with a strong and growing tax base of high-quality residential and commercial development.  The city has received national recognition for its Comprehensive Infrastructure Replacement Plan and has a Standard and Poor's bond rating of AAA
column2: placing Shoreview in the top 12% of Minnesota government entities.

column1: The city of Shoreview contracts with the Ramsey County Sheriff's Department for police services and has one of the lowest crime rates among similar cities in the metropolitan area.

the city adopted a new Comprehensive Guide Plan that serves as the framework for directing future land use and development decisions.  The city also has an ongoing economic development program to retain and attract businesses that enhance the tax base and serve residents.

column1: Shoreview's water system consists of six wells
column2: two 1.5-million gallon elevated storage tanks
column4: and more than 100 miles of water main.  The water system has a total pumping capacity of 14.4 million gallons per day
column5: with an average daily demand of 3.2 million gallons and a peak demand of 10.6 million gallons per day.  The city maintains 108 miles of city owned sewer laterals and 17 lift stations.  Sewer trunk lines and treatment facilities are owned by the Metropolitan Council Wastewater

column1: Services MCWS).  Xcel Energy provides electricity and natural gas service to city residents.  Along with this
column2: the city maintains 88 miles of residential and collector streets.

column1: 1837 - Dakota and Ojibwe Indians once inhabited the area that is now Shoreview.  Indian mounds containing human bone

column2: arrowheads
column4: and bits of charcoal have been found on Rice Creek near the north shore of

column1: Long Lake in nearby New Brighton and in parts of Shamrock Park.  In 1837 the land lying between the St. Croix and Mississippi Rivers
column2: including what is now Shoreview
column3: was ceded to the United States Government by the Ojibwe.

Shoreview was part of the former Mounds View Township.  The name came from a range of hills running through

column1: the center of the township.  Mounds View Township was organized on May 11
1880 - Later in the 1800s railroad lines expanded to include Shoreview.  The first railroad lines in Shoreview
column2: owned by James "The Puck" McMillan and his Duluth
column3: South Shore and Atlantic Railway (now Soo Lines) were built in the 1880s.

column3: feeling the inadequacy of a township government

column1: Ramsey County Board of Commissioners that called for the incorporation of the Village of Shoreview.  This action
would separate Shoreview from Mounds View Township.  After a bitter dispute
column2: an election was held at the Shamrock Park pavilion and the incorporation of Shoreview was approved by a vote of 853 to 748.

column1: Citizens worked to change the form of government
column2: and on November 5
column4: in order to better deal with the village's growing population
column5: the citizens of Shoreview voted to shift to a “Plan A” form of government under which the village clerk and treasurer were appointed rather than elected.

column2: 1973 community leaders decided it was time to build a City Hall.  A referendum was passed by a single vote and a structure was built.  This was the site of Shoreview's government until 1990 when the City Hall and Community Center opened at Shoreview Commons.

column1: 1974 - Shoreview changed forms of government once again and became a city on January 1
column2: 1974 through an act of the State Legislature.  With a population of over 14
column4: the residents voted in November 1974 to adopt the present “Plan B” Council-Manager form of government.

column1: 2007 - Shoreview celebrated its golden anniversary with a ceremony at Shamrock Park recognizing residents living in the community since its incorporation.

2011 - Shoreview Maintenance Center renovated/received the LEED Gold Certification by the Green Building Council. This was the first in the nation to be certified under the 2009 LEED rating system and only the fifth city facility in the state to be LEED certified.  Mayor Martin received the C.C.Ludwig Award for outstanding service and leadership from the League of Minnesota Cities.
